title: Saia Fainga'a
text:
Saia Fainga'a (born 2 February 1987) is an Australian professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer.
Family and early life.
Saia Fainga'a was born in <a href="Queanbeyan%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Queanbeyan, New South Wales</a>, and started playing rugby union at the age of 11 or 12 at the <a href="Queanbeyan%20Whites">Queanbeyan</a> club. He was a member of the <a href="Brumbies">Brumbies</a> Academy from the age of 14 and attended <a href="St%20Edmund%27s%20College%2C%20Canberra">St Edmund's College, Canberra</a>, where he was selected for the <a href="Australian%20Schoolboys%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australian Schools</a> team in 2003 and 2004.
Saia's twin brother <a href="Anthony%20Fainga%27a">Anthony</a>, and younger brothers <a href="Vili%20Fainga%27a">Vili</a> and <a href="Colby%20Fainga%27a">Colby</a> are also professional rugby union players. The Fainga'a's are of <a href="Tonga">Tonga</a>n English and <a href="Italian%20people">Italian</a> descent.
Career.
Fainga'a made his <a href="Super%2014">Super 14</a> debut in 2006. He was fast-tracked into the Brumbies' side due to injuries in the squad, and played his first senior match for the Brumbies against the <a href="Stormers">Stormers</a> in Cape Town. Later that year he captained the Australian Under 19s team to win the <a href="Under%2019%20Rugby%20World%20Championship">IRB World Championship</a> in Dubai. Fainga'a went on to earn 27 super rugby caps at the Brumbies from 2006 to 2008.
In 2008, Saia and his twin brother Anthony signed on to play with the <a href="Queensland%20Reds">Queensland Reds</a> for the <a href="2009%20Queensland%20Reds%20season">2009 season</a>. He made his Test debut for <a href="Wallabies%20%28rugby%20union%29">Australia</a> in 2010 against Fiji in <a href="Canberra">Canberra</a>.
He played in all 18 matches of the Reds <a href="2011%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2011 Super Rugby</a> title-winning season, and was selected alongside his brother Anthony in the Wallabies squad for the 2011 Rugby World Cup in New Zealand, where Australia took third place.
On 2 June 2017 it was announced he would move to England after signing for newly promoted Premiership side <a href="London%20Irish">London Irish</a>. He was released ahead of the 2020–21 season.
